name: WCAG Content Accessibility Guidelines
approach: Create content that meets WCAG 2.1 AA standards by ensuring proper heading hierarchy, descriptive link text, meaningful alt text for images, sufficient color contrast, and readable content structure. Content should be perceivable, operable, understandable, and robust for all users.
rationale: Accessible content reaches a wider audience including the 15% of the global population with disabilities. It also improves SEO, user experience for all visitors, and ensures legal compliance with accessibility regulations like ADA and EAA.

title: "Accessible Content Guide"
description: "Learn how to create content that everyone can use."
---

# How to Write Accessible Content

This guide helps you create content that works for everyone.

## Use Clear Headings

Headings help people navigate your content. Use them in order:

- One H1 per page (the main title)
- H2 for major sections
- H3 for subsections

## Write Descriptive Links

Instead of "click here," describe where the link goes:

- **Don't:** For more info, [click here](#).
- **Do:** Read our [accessibility guidelines](#).

## Add Alt Text to Images

Describe what's in the image:

![A developer reviewing code on two monitors, with a cup of coffee nearby](./dev-workspace.jpg)

## Use Lists for Multiple Items

When you have three or more related items:

1. First, identify your content goals
2. Then, outline your structure
3. Finally, write clear, simple sentences

success_indicators: Heading hierarchy is logical (H1 > H2 > H3, no skipped levels)
All links have descriptive text (no 'click here')
All informative images have meaningful alt text
Color is not the only way to convey information
Content is at grade 8-9 reading level for general audiences
Lists are used for 3+ related items
Sufficient color contrast (4.5:1 for text, 3:1 for large text)
